levels.description: Welcome to Level 1 focusing on General Phishing Attempts. Were you aware that phishing attacks are increasingly prevalent in our digital era? According to a 2022 report from the FBI’s Cyber Crime Complaint Center, phishing has been among the top five cyber crimes for 5 years in a row, with +240,000 incidents and losses exceeding $52 million. Despite their innocent appearance, these messages can have serious consequences. By learning how to identify and thwart basic phishing attempts, you can protect yourself and your loved ones from cyber threats.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Look carefully and pick the right answer before the timer runs out, if you get stuck you can unlock a hint.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Congratulations! You've been selected to receive a 500SAR Amazon gift card. Click here to claim:
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.text: This message is not a fraudulent attempt
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: It is a fraudulent attempt using suspicious link.

scenarios.hint: Look for red flags like unknown numbers and offers that seem too good to be true.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Be cautious! Messages about package deliveries can sometimes be misleading. Always verify the source before clicking any links.
scenarios.receivedMessage: If you are the owner of order No. 8987, your package is waiting for you! Click here to confirm delivery:
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Is this a phishing attempt? If so, what is the indication?
This is the official link for Saudi Post SPL.

scenarios.hint: Look for red flags such as unexpected links or requests for personal information, even if the contact appears official.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Prize notifications from unknown sources can often be scams. Always verify before responding.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Congratulations! You’ve been selected for a cash prize. Click the link to claim!
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Not all prize notifications are scams.
It is a fraudulent attempt with a suspicious link.

scenarios.hint: Cash prize notifications from unknown contacts should raise immediate suspicion.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Stay vigilant! Messages claiming unusual activity on your accounts often aim to steal your personal information.
scenarios.receivedMessage: We've noticed unusual activity on your bank account. Please confirm your details to secure your account.
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Such notices can be legitimate.
It is a fraudulent attempt requesting sensitive information.

scenarios.hint: Legitimate companies will never ask for sensitive information via unsecured channels.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Be alert! Messages offering free gifts often come with hidden traps. Always be skeptical of requests for personal information.
scenarios.receivedMessage: You've been randomly selected to receive a free iPhone! Reply with your address to claim.
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Urgent tone is one of the phishing methods but it was not in this message.
It is a fraudulent attempt asking for personal details.

scenarios.hint: Offers that require you to give personal information are often scams.

levels.description: Welcome to Level 2 focusing on Brand Impersonation. Did you know that brand impersonation is a sophisticated form of phishing that exploits our trust in well-known companies? In 2020, Twitter was hacked and trusted accounts, including those of Bill Gates and Elon Musk, were impersonated to promote a Bitcoin scam. The incident resulted in over $100,000 being stolen in just a few hours.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Look carefully and pick the right answer before the timer runs out, if you get stuck you can unlock a hint.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Dear Customer, your Netflix account is on hold due to billing issues. Please verify your payment information here:
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Account holds can happen for legitimate reasons.
It is a fraudulent attempt using a spoofed link.

scenarios.hint: Always check the sender's details and the link before taking action.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Be cautious! Messages claiming suspicious activity on your accounts often aim to trick you into sharing sensitive information.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Your Google account has been flagged for suspicious activity. Please respond with your password to verify your identity.
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Account flags can happen legitimately.
It is a fraudulent attempt asking for sensitive information.

scenarios.hint: Never share your password in response to messages, even if they seem urgent.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Stay alert! Messages about account issues often try to create a sense of urgency. Always check with official channels.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Your Apple ID has been locked due to suspicious activity. Please call this number to unlock it: +966 12 345 6789.
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Legitimate companies won't ask you to call for account issues.
Account issues can happen.
It is a fraudulent attempt using a spoofed number.

scenarios.hint: Legitimate companies usually provide secure online options for account issues.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Be cautious of messages announcing winnings. Scammers often use prize notifications to collect personal information. Verify before responding!
scenarios.receivedMessage: Congratulations! You've won a 100SAR gift card from Amazon. Just reply with your email to claim.
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Winning notifications can be real.
It is a fraudulent attempt asking for personal information.

scenarios.hint: Never give out personal information to claim prizes from unknown sources.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Be wary! Messages claiming to be from famous individuals, especially asking for personal details, are often scams.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Hi, it's Elon Musk! Your Tesla account needs immediate verification. Please confirm your details to avoid suspension.
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Messages from celebrities can be real, but context matters.
Legitimate companies usually don’t pressure you for immediate confirmations.
It is a fraudulent attempt using a celebrity's name.

scenarios.hint: Be suspicious of urgent requests, even from well-known figures.

levels.description: Welcome to Level 3 focusing on Personalization Tactics. Did you know that in May 2023, a serious data breach occurred at Tesla that exposed the personal data of 75,000 individuals? This left customers vulnerable to phishing attacks due to the sensitive information leaked. These tailored approaches, known as spear-phishing, are particularly dangerous because they can appear highly convincing. Learning to spot these personalized tactics is essential for maintaining your privacy and security.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Look carefully and pick the right answer before the timer runs out. If you get stuck, you can unlock a hint.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Hello! Your Jeddah University Blackboard account is at risk. Please send your account password to secure your access.
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Risk alerts can be real.
Legitimate companies won’t ask you about your password.
Generic greetings can appear in real messages.
It is a fraudulent attempt.

scenarios.hint: Always verify account alerts by logging in directly through the official site.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Pay attention to the details. Scammers often use a mix of true and false information.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Urgent: Your Jeddah University email storage is full. To prevent loss of important academic emails, verify your account here:
scenarios.question: What makes this message likely to be a phishing attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Using the correct institution name doesn't guarantee authenticity.
Email storage warnings can be legitimate.

answers.text: Asking to verify account via a link
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Legitimate IT departments typically don't ask for verification through unexpected links.
This is a phishing attempt using your university email information.

scenarios.hint: Official communications about university accounts should come through established, secure channels.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Analyze the message carefully. Remember, personalized information doesn't guarantee authenticity.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Hello, The book you were looking for has arrived! Please provide your student ID and credit card details to buy it.
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.text: Knowing the book you were looking for
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: The library does know the books we look for.
The university library wouldn't ask for credit card information via a message.
There was no suspicious link.
This is a phishing attempt exploiting your library usage.

scenarios.hint: University services usually handle payments through official channels, not through informal messages.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Messages claiming you've won something based on your visit can often be scams! Always verify the source before clicking any links or providing personal information.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Congratulations! Your recent visit to Jeddah Waterfront was our 1000th today. Claim your free VIP pass for all Jeddah Season events here:
scenarios.question: What makes this message suspicious?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: The waterfront is a popular location; mentioning it doesn't make the message suspicious.
Events sometimes do offer prizes, but be cautious of unexpected ones.
Jeddah Season wouldn't typically track individual visits to public spaces.
This is a phishing attempt using a popular local event.

scenarios.hint: Be wary of unexpected prizes that require you to click on links, especially when they claim to have tracked your movements.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Remember, scammers can access some of your public information. Stay alert!
scenarios.receivedMessage: Hello, you have won a shopping voucher worth 5000 riyals at Red Sea Mall. Just provide us with the code that was sent to your phone.
scenarios.question: What is the primary indicator that this is a phishing attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: There is no link in the message.
Shopping malls sometimes run promotions with big prizes.

answers.text: Request to claim the prize by sending a code.

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: This is a sophisticated phishing attempt using a popular local shopping destination.

scenarios.hint: Be wary of unexpected big prizes, especially when claimed via a link or code rather than in person.

levels.description: Welcome to Level 4 focusing on Urgency and Threats. Did you know that PayPal, one of the largest online payment systems, was attacked by hackers to steal customer account information? The criminals send thousands of emails in an attempt to scare users with a tone of urgency that they must provide their information or their accounts will be closed unless they act quickly and click on a link. The cybercriminals are then able to use this information to steal money from users’ PayPal accounts.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Remember, urgent messages often aim to make you act without thinking. Stay calm and analyze carefully.
scenarios.receivedMessage: URGENT: Your vehicle has been caught speeding on King Abdullah Road. Pay the 500 SAR fine within 1 hour to avoid license suspension:
scenarios.question: What's the main indicator that this is likely a scam?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Traffic systems do have access to vehicle information.
Real traffic violations often include location details.
Official fines don't require such immediate payment, especially not via a text message link.
This is a scam using urgency to pressure you into quick action.

scenarios.hint: Official traffic fines allow reasonable time for payment and use formal channels, not rushed text message links.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Threats of account closure or service interruption are common tactics. Stay vigilant!
scenarios.receivedMessage: WARNING: Your mobile service will be terminated in 30 minutes due to suspicious activity. Verify your identity immediately to prevent disconnection:
scenarios.question: What makes this message suspicious?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Service providers do monitor for unusual activity.
Providers may suspend service for security reasons, but usually not this quickly.

answers.text: Demanding immediate verification via a link
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Legitimate providers would ask you to contact them directly or log in to your account, not click a link.
This is a phishing attempt using the threat of service loss to provoke hasty action.

scenarios.hint: Real service providers give more time and use official channels for identity verification.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Financial threats are common in phishing. Always verify through official channels before taking action.
scenarios.receivedMessage: CRITICAL: Unusual 10,000 SAR transfer detected from your account. If not you, click here to block your card immediately:
scenarios.question: Despite the urgency, what indicates this could be a phishing attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Banks do alert about specific suspicious transactions.
Banks send alerts for potentially fraudulent activities.

answers.text: Providing a direct link to block the card
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Legitimate banks ask you to log in to your account directly or call their official number, not click a link.
This is a sophisticated phishing attempt using financial fear to provoke immediate action.

scenarios.hint: For any urgent banking issues, always contact your bank directly through their official app or phone number.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Scammers often exploit academic stress. Stay calm and verify information through official channels.
scenarios.receivedMessage: URGENT: Your graduation status is at risk due to a missing credit. Submit your updated transcript and 500 SAR processing fee within 2 hours to secure your degree:
scenarios.question: What's the primary indicator that this is likely a phishing attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Universities do send alerts about graduation requirements.
Transcripts are often needed for degree verification.

answers.text: Demanding a fee via a link with a short deadline
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Legitimate universities don't request urgent fee payments through text message links, especially for graduation status.
This is a scam exploiting the stress of graduation to prompt hasty action.

scenarios.hint: Universities handle graduation issues through official channels with reasonable timelines, not via urgent text messages with payment links.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Scammers may exploit religious events and charitable giving. Stay vigilant, especially during holy times.
scenarios.receivedMessage: URGENT: Your Zakat payment for Ramadan is overdue. Pay within 1 hour to ensure it's counted before Eid. Pay here:
scenarios.question: What's the main red flag indicating this is likely a phishing attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Mosques and Islamic organizations do remind about Zakat obligations.
Religious reminders often mention specific holy days and periods.

answers.text: Demanding payment within 1 hour via a link
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Legitimate religious organizations don't set such urgent deadlines for Zakat, nor do they typically collect it through text message links.
This is a scam exploiting religious obligations and the urgency of the holy month.

scenarios.hint: While Zakat is important, there's no religious basis for such urgent deadlines. Legitimate organizations provide various secure methods for Zakat payment without rushing you.

levels.description: Welcome to Level 5 focusing on Social Engineering Techniques. Social engineering is the psychological manipulation of people to get them to take actions or reveal confidential information. A famous example of this is the Uber data breach, where attackers used social engineering to gain access to Uber’s GitHub account, ultimately compromising the data of 57 million users and drivers. These sophisticated attacks prove that cybersecurity isn’t just about technology, it’s about understanding human behavior and decision-making processes.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Look carefully and pick the right answer before the timer runs out. If you get stuck, you can unlock a hint.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Hey! I’m your friend from college, but I lost my phone. Can you send me your bank details for an urgent transfer? I promise to pay you back!
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: People do lose their phones; verify first.
Never share bank details, even with friends.

answers.text: I promise to pay you back
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Promises can be made in genuine situations.
Urgency can be a tactic in real emergencies.
Requests for help can be genuine.

scenarios.hint: Always verify requests through a different communication method.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Be aware! Scammers often use enticing offers to lure you in. Always check the legitimacy of promotions.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Congratulations! You’ve been selected for a VIP exclusive sale at your favorite store! Click here to access your early bird discount:
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Exclusive offers can be real.

answers.text: Click here to access your discount
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Links in unsolicited messages are often phishing attempts.
Congratulatory messages can be legitimate.
Discounts can be attractive but verify them.
Urgency can be used in genuine promotions.

scenarios.hint: Always check the retailer’s official website for promotions.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Remember! Scammers often create fake alerts to provoke immediate reactions. Always verify account alerts independently.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Hi! This is a reminder from your favorite restaurant for a special invitation to our members-only event. Please confirm your attendance by providing your card details.
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Restaurants may send event invitations.
Legitimate establishments won’t ask for card details via text.
Exclusive events can be real.
Confirmation requests can happen.
Exclusivity can be part of real promotions.

scenarios.hint: Always confirm special event invitations directly with the establishment.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Stay alert! Scammers often impersonate trusted organizations to extract sensitive information. Always verify through official channels.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Important security alert: Your account was accessed from a new device. To secure your account, please reply with your security code.
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Account access alerts can be legitimate.
Legitimate companies will never ask for security codes via text.
Urgent alerts can be real.
New device alerts are common.
Urgency can be part of real alerts.

scenarios.hint: Always check your account security settings through the official website or app.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Don’t be fooled! Scammers often use fake surveys to collect personal data. Always verify before sharing information.
scenarios.receivedMessage: We’re conducting a survey to improve our services. Complete it and receive a $50 gift card! Click this link:
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Surveys can be legitimate.
Offers for free gift cards often indicate fraud.
Links in unsolicited messages are often phishing attempts.
Completing surveys can be normal.
Improvement requests can be genuine.

scenarios.hint: Be wary of unsolicited surveys promising rewards.

levels.description: Did you know? Advanced phishing attacks, utilizing cutting-edge technologies and AI enhancements, are on the rise. In a notable case from 2019, cybercriminals used AI to mimic a CEO's voice, tricking an employee into transferring $243,000 to a fraudulent account. This highlights the evolving of cybercrime tactics and the need for enhanced vigilance and understanding of technology manipulation in combating such threats.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Look carefully and pick the right answer before the timer runs out. If you get stuck, you can unlock a hint.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Dear Valued Customer, we detected unusual activity in your account this morning. To ensure your funds are safe, please verify your identity immediately:
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Legitimate alerts may indicate unusual activity.
Legitimate companies will not ask for immediate verification via unsolicited links.
Generic salutations are common in real communications.

answers.text: To ensure your funds are safe
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Safety assurances can be part of real alerts.
Specific timing can add credibility.

scenarios.hint: Always verify alerts by logging into your account through the official site.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Advanced phishing often leverages social engineering techniques to create a sense of trust. Always double-check the sender's identity and context.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Hi! This is Mark from your HR department. We need to conduct a mandatory survey about employee benefits. Please complete it here:
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.text: This is Mark from your HR department
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: HR requests can be legitimate.
Surveys can be part of real HR activities.
Legitimate surveys will not typically request links via text.
Mandatory requests can seem urgent.
Casual greetings can occur in real communications.

scenarios.hint: Verify any HR requests by contacting your HR department directly.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Be cautious! Phishing attacks can impersonate known services with minor changes. Always check for misspellings and unusual URLs.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Your Amazon account has been compromised! Click this link to secure your account (Failure to do so may result in suspension).
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.text: Your Amazon account has been compromised
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Compromise alerts can be real.

answers.text: Click this link to secure your account
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Legitimate companies will not ask you to click links in unsolicited messages.

answers.text: Failure to do so may result in suspension
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Suspension warnings can be genuine.
Security requests can happen.
Urgency can be a tactic in real alerts.

scenarios.hint: Always log in directly to your account to check for security notifications.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Phishers often create fake but realistic scenarios to manipulate you. Always verify the authenticity of any unexpected requests for action.
scenarios.receivedMessage: Congratulations! You've won a free trip to Paris! To claim your prize, please confirm your identity by clicking this link:
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: If it sounds too good to be true, it usually is.
Legitimate prizes don’t require action via unsolicited links.
Winning notifications can be real.
Legitimate companies will not ask for personal information via unsolicited messages.
Links in unsolicited messages are often phishing attempts.

scenarios.hint: Never click on links in unsolicited prize notifications; verify through official channels.

scenarios.startingCharacterMessage: Remember! Advanced phishing attacks can look remarkably authentic, even using logos and branding. Always scrutinize every detail before acting.
scenarios.receivedMessage: This is a security notification from Netflex. We detected abnormal usage on your account. Please confirm your account information here including the password.
scenarios.question: What was the indication that this message is a fraudulent attempt?

answers.text: Security notification from your internet service provider
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Such notifications can be legitimate.

answers.text: Detected abnormal usage on your account
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Usage alerts can happen in real contexts.

answers.text: Please confirm your account information here
answers.explanationWhenIncorrect: Legitimate companies will not ask for account information via unsolicited links.
Security alerts can be genuine.
Abnormal usage can trigger real alerts.

scenarios.hint: Always contact your service provider directly to verify any security notifications.
